page.title: 14Bridges of Pontrhydyfen.
page.content: Pontrhydyfen is well known for its two arched bridges.The now dis-used railway{viaduct}was the last railway bridge to be built in the Afan Valley and unlike many of the others it was built of brick.It was last used in {1962}when the railway line was closed. The{aqueduct}is the most well known as it is the oldest surviving bridge in the valley, having been built in 1825 to supply water to the Blast Furnaces in Oakwood. It has 4 arches,is 459ft in length,75ft in height and 14ft wide.The bridge cost Â£16,000 pounds to build.Now it is used for cars and pedestrians.In February 1985 cracks were discovered on the Aqueduct and it was closed,thus cutting off a pedestrian access to Oakwood. There is now scaffolding over the top of it. They might have to pull it down, who knows? E.L.
